article.p: Why BCHS? Because the open Internet is the most hostile landscape around.

section.p: When we say BSD, we mean OpenBSD. Why? Documentation. Security. Reliable six-month releases. Take the guess-work out of your environment. Did we mention documentation?
Learn C like the proper way: by reading The C Programming Language. It's a straightforward, non-mustachioed language.
OpenBSD features the simple, home-grown httpd(8) right out of the box. It also includes slowcgi(8) for non-FastCGI applications. If you need more features for your web application, start rethinking.
Ok, if SQLite is a too light-weight for you, use PostgreSQL. But for any normal web application, SQLite is the way. It's also installed in the base system—simple.

article.p: BCHS isn't just a software stack. It's stable, developer-oriented tools for handling data in an incredibly scary environment. Get used to minimalism: statically-compiled, privilege-separated binaries in file-system jails. Use powerful system tools directly instead of depending on PHP to hold your hand. And most of all, forget your LAMP instincts to desperately Google and StackExchange every parameter: man pages are your new best friend.
Need help with CGI handling? Like with any hipster languages, you've plenty of package options like FastCGI or kcgi. Most other libraries (PNG handling, etc.) can be found in the same place.

footer.div: Built on OpenBSD: greasy fingers, greasy spine.
